anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
who win road march in trinidad and tobago
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['After a German pop song "Happy Wanderer" by the Obernkirchen Children\'s Choir won the Trinidad & Tobago Road March title in 1955 the rules were amended to restrict songs eligible to be in the road march competition to only songs vocalised by local Trinidad & Tobago artistes. The Road March title is among the most prestigious in Trinidad Carnival. The most such titles have gone to the late Lord Kitchener with eleven wins, ahead of Super Blue with ten wins, Machel Montano also with ten wins and the Mighty Sparrow with eight wins. In the mid-1970s, a woman officially broke through in the male dominated Calypso arena. Calypso Rose was the first female to officially win the Trinidad and Tobago Road March competition in 1977 with her song "Give More Tempo". The following year 1978 with "Come Leh We Jam" in addition to winning the Road March title again, Calypso Rose also won the "Calypso King" competition, the first time a woman had received that award. As a result, the "Calypso King" competition was officially renamed the "Calypso Monarch" competition to take into account that females also take part and have won titles.\n', 'Destra won the Road March title in 2003 at the Labour Day Carnival in Brooklyn, and also placed second in the Trinidad and Tobago Soca Monarch competition in that same year.\n', 'Invader has won the Road March in St. Lucia seven times. In a period from 1970-1972 and again from 1974-1976, Road March winners were imported from Trinidad and Tobago.\n', "Fay-Ann Lyons is a three-time Trinidad and Tobago Carnival Road March champion (2003, 2008, 2009) and the 2009 International Soca Monarch and International Groovy Soca Monarch champion. She created history (again) when she won the International Soca Monarch for the first time in 2009, as the first female to win the Power category, and the first individual (male or female) to win the Power, Groovy and People's Choice awards on Fantastic Friday (aka Carnival Friday) during the finals of the competition which is held annually in Trinidad. She also went on to win the Carnival Road March that year, becoming the first soca artist to win that soca 'triplet' of titles. She is the first (and only) woman to accomplish that feat while pregnant. Fay-Ann is the youngest solo artist (male or female), still actively recording, with multiple wins of the Carnival Road March crown. (Machel Montano is the youngest male with multiple wins, now that he has four solo wins and a joint win with Patrice Roberts). Fay-Ann remains the only female artist who has won the Carnival Road March three times, and is the second to attain back-to-back wins in two consecutive years joining Alison Hinds Of Barbados who won 2 road march titles in 1996 and 1997. Fay-Ann and husband Bunji Garlin also became parents in 2009 to a daughter, Syri, born on February 28, 2009, just a few weeks after Carnival. Fay-Ann has performed at musical events both locally and abroad. Her on-tour performance evGents and locations include: Washington DC (2009) & (2017) BET's 106 & Park (2014), Coachella (2015), Glastonbury Festival (2015), London's Coronet (2015), Berlin Carnival-Germany and, BET X Live (2018).\n", 'Trinidad and Tobago competed at the 2016 UCI Track Cycling World Championships at the Lee Valley VeloPark in London, United Kingdom from 2-4 March 2016. A team of 1 cyclists (0 women, 1 men) was announced to represent the country in the event.\n', 'On June 16, 2019, Ramey represented Five Rivers was crowned as Miss Trinidad and Tobago 2019 held at Naparima Bowl in San Fernando. She succeeded outgoing by Ysabel Bisnath. \n', 'In Trinidad and Tobago the Road March title has been officially given out every year since 1932 (with the exception of the years affected by World War I and World War II when Carnival did not officially take place). Popular Unofficial Road Marches have also been recognized in T&T from since 1834 after slavery was abolished. Prior to World War II, T&T Road Marches were referred to as "Leggos" or "Breakaways" by the general population but were rebranded by the Carnival authorities as the Road March from 1946. Scoring is based upon a register-and-count system devised by a Carnival committee before the start of the parade. \n', '• Tour of Trinidad and Tobago Champion 2013\n', 'First Calypso recordings were made in 1912 so Trinidad & Tobago Road Marches prior to 1912 were not recorded that year but may have been recorded years later after recording technology became available to Calypso pioneers of 1910\'s to 1930\'s. In 2019 Skinny Fabulous of St. Vincent & the Grenadines created history by becoming the second foreign artiste (after the German Obernkirchen Children\'s Choir) and the very first foreign soca artiste to win the prestigious Trinidad & Tobago Road March title with a song called "Famalay" which was vocalised by Skinny Fabulous, Machel Montano and Bunji Garllin. \n', 'In 2015, Trinidad and Tobago won the NACRA Rugby Championship, defeating Mexico 30-16 in the final.\n']

Task Description:
Please extract content that may be unfamiliar to the model from these passages, 
which can provide the model with relevant background and unknown knowledge and concepts,

To effectively answer the question regarding who has won the Road March title in Trinidad and Tobago, we can extract and analyze several key pieces of information from the provided passages. Here’s a breakdown of the relevant content and its significance:

1. **Historical Context of the Road March**:
   - The Road March title has been awarded annually since 1932, with exceptions during World War I and World War II. This establishes the long-standing tradition and importance of the competition within Trinidad and Tobago's Carnival culture.

2. **Eligibility and Rules**:
   - The rules were amended after a non-local song won in 1955, restricting eligibility to songs by local Trinidad and Tobago artists. This highlights the cultural significance of local artistry in the competition and the desire to promote indigenous talent.

3. **Notable Winners**:
   - **Lord Kitchener**: Holds the record with eleven wins, indicating his prominence in the calypso genre and the Road March competition.
   - **Super Blue and Machel Montano**: Both have ten wins, showcasing their significant contributions to the soca genre and the competition.
   - **Calypso Rose**: The first female winner in 1977, she broke gender barriers in a male-dominated field, winning again in 1978. Her achievements are pivotal in understanding the evolution of gender roles in Trinidadian music.
   - **Fay-Ann Lyons**: A three-time champion (2003, 2008, 2009) and the first female to win multiple titles, she represents the modern era of female empowerment in the soca genre. Her unique achievement of winning multiple titles while pregnant adds another layer to her significance.

4. **Recent Developments**:
   - In 2019, **Skinny Fabulous** became the first foreign soca artist to win the Road March title with the song "Famalay." This indicates a shift in the competition's dynamics, allowing for broader participation and recognition of Caribbean artists beyond Trinidad and Tobago.

5. **Cultural Significance**:
   - The Road March title is described as one of the most prestigious awards in Trinidad Carnival, underscoring its importance in the cultural identity and celebration of Trinidad and Tobago.

### Role of Extracted Content:
- **Cultural Understanding**: The historical context and rules surrounding the Road March provide insight into its significance in Trinidadian culture, emphasizing local artistry and the evolution of the competition.
- **Recognition of Talent**: Highlighting notable winners and their contributions helps illustrate the competitive landscape and the impact of individual artists on the genre.
- **Gender Dynamics**: The achievements of female artists like Calypso Rose and Fay-Ann Lyons reflect changing societal norms and the growing recognition of women in the music industry.
- **Inclusivity**: The recent win by a foreign artist signals a potential shift towards a more inclusive understanding of Caribbean music, which could influence future competitions.

By synthesizing this information, one can better appreciate the nuances of the Road March competition and its significance in Trinidad and Tobago's cultural landscape, ultimately aiding in answering the question of who has won the title.

The retrieved passages provide a comprehensive overview of the Trinidad and Tobago Road March competition, highlighting its history, notable winners, and the significance of the title within the context of Trinidad Carnival. Here’s a summary and analysis of the key points:

### Key Points:

1. **Historical Context**:
   - The Road March title has been awarded annually since 1932, with interruptions during World War I and II. It was originally referred to as "Leggos" or "Breakaways" before being rebranded as the Road March in 1946.
   - The competition was influenced by a German pop song in 1955, leading to a rule change that restricted eligible songs to those performed by local Trinidad and Tobago artists.

2. **Notable Winners**:
   - **Lord Kitchener** holds the record for the most Road March titles, with eleven wins.
   - **Super Blue** and **Machel Montano** have each won the title ten times, while **The Mighty Sparrow** has eight wins.
   - **Calypso Rose** was the first female winner in 1977 and won again in 1978, marking a significant moment in the competition's history.
   - **Fay-Ann Lyons** is notable for winning the Road March three times (2003, 2008, 2009) and is recognized as the first female artist to achieve multiple wins. She also made history by winning the International Soca Monarch titles in 2009.

3. **Recent Developments**:
   - In 2019, **Skinny Fabulous** became the first foreign soca artist to win the Road March title with the song "Famalay," which featured local artists Machel Montano and Bunji Garlin.

4. **Cultural Significance**:
   - The Road March title is considered one of the most prestigious awards in Trinidad Carnival, reflecting the cultural importance of music and performance in the celebration.
   - The competition has evolved to include a diverse range of artists and has become a platform for both local and international talent.

### Analysis of Role and Importance:

The content from the passages serves several roles:

- **Cultural Insight**: It provides insight into the cultural fabric of Trinidad and Tobago, emphasizing the significance of the Road March in the Carnival festivities and its role in promoting local music and artists.
  
- **Historical Understanding**: The historical context enriches the understanding of how the competition has evolved over time, including changes in eligibility and the impact of international influences.

- **Recognition of Diversity**: The mention of female artists and foreign winners highlights the increasing inclusivity and diversity within the competition, showcasing the changing dynamics in a traditionally male-dominated space.

- **Celebration of Achievement**: The detailed accounts of past winners and their contributions to the music scene underscore the importance of recognizing artistic achievements and the legacy of these artists in shaping the Carnival experience.

### Conclusion:

By consolidating this information, one can appreciate the depth of the Trinidad and Tobago Road March competition, not just as a musical contest but as a vital cultural event that reflects the nation’s identity, history, and evolving artistic landscape. Understanding these elements enhances the comprehension of the question regarding who wins the Road March, as it situates individual achievements within a broader cultural and historical narrative.

Calypso Rose made history as the first female winner in 1977, and Fay-Ann Lyons is recognized for her three wins (2003, 2008, 2009), marking significant milestones for female artists in the competition.

Fay-Ann has performed at musical events both locally and abroad. Her on-tour performance evGents and locations include: Washington DC (2009) & (2017) BET's 106 & Park (2014), Coachella (2015), Glastonbury Festival (2015), London's Coronet (2015), Berlin Carnival-Germany and, BET X Live (2018).
", 'Trinidad and Tobago competed at the 2016 UCI Track Cycling World Championships at the Lee Valley VeloPark in London, United Kingdom from 2-4 March 2016. A team of 1 cyclists (0 women, 1 men) was announced to represent the country in the event.
', 'On June 16, 2019, Ramey represented Five Rivers was crowned as Miss Trinidad and Tobago 2019 held at Naparima Bowl in San Fernando. She succeeded outgoing by Ysabel Bisnath. 
', 'In Trinidad and Tobago the Road March title has been officially given out every year since 1932 (with the exception of the years affected by World War I and World War II when Carnival did not officially take place). Popular Unofficial Road Marches have also been recognized in T&T from since 1834 after slavery was abolished. Prior to World War II, T&T Road Marches were referred to as "Leggos" or "Breakaways" by the general population but were rebranded by the Carnival authorities as the Road March from 1946. Scoring is based upon a register-and-count system devised by a Carnival committee before the start of the parade. 
', '• Tour of Trinidad and Tobago Champion 2013
', 'First Calypso recordings were made in 1912 so Trinidad & Tobago Road Marches prior to 1912 were not recorded that year but may have been recorded years later after recording technology became available to Calypso pioneers of 1910's to 1930's. In 2019 Skinny Fabulous of St. Vincent & the Grenadines created history by becoming the second foreign artiste (after the German Obernkirchen Children's Choir) and the very first foreign soca artiste to win the prestigious Trinidad & Tobago Road March title with a song called "Famalay" which was vocalised by Skinny Fabulous, Machel Montano and Bunji Garllin. 
', 'In 2015, Trinidad and Tobago won the NACRA Rugby Championship, defeating Mexico 30-16 in the final.
']

Task Description:
Please extract content from these passages that can help enhance the model's causal reasoning and logical inference abilities.
consolidate these contents, and analyze how the selected information may impact the improvement of the model's causal reasoning and logical inference capabilities.

To enhance the model's causal reasoning and logical inference abilities, we can extract and consolidate relevant information from the provided passages about the Trinidad and Tobago Road March competition. Here’s a summary of the key points and their implications:

### Extracted Information:
1. **Historical Context**:
   - The Road March title has been awarded annually since 1932, with exceptions during World Wars I and II.
   - The competition was rebranded from "Leggos" or "Breakaways" to "Road March" in 1946.

2. **Eligibility Rules**:
   - Initially, the competition allowed songs from non-local artists, but this changed after a German song won in 1955, leading to a restriction to local Trinidad and Tobago artists.

3. **Notable Winners**:
   - Lord Kitchener holds the record with eleven wins.
   - Super Blue and Machel Montano each have ten wins.
   - Calypso Rose was the first female winner in 1977.
   - Fay-Ann Lyons is a three-time champion (2003, 2008, 2009) and the first female to win multiple times.
   - In 2019, Skinny Fabulous became the first foreign soca artist to win with "Famalay."

4. **Cultural Significance**:
   - The Road March title is one of the most prestigious awards in Trinidad Carnival, highlighting its importance in local culture.

### Analysis of Impact on Causal Reasoning and Logical Inference:
1. **Understanding Causality**:
   - The change in eligibility rules after the 1955 incident illustrates how outcomes (winning by a non-local artist) can lead to changes in regulations. This helps the model understand cause-and-effect relationships in competitive contexts.

2. **Pattern Recognition**:
   - The repeated wins by certain artists (e.g., Lord Kitchener, Machel Montano) can help the model identify patterns and infer potential factors contributing to success, such as popularity, style, or cultural resonance.

3. **Historical Contextualization**:
   - Knowing the historical context of the competition allows the model to make inferences about the evolution of cultural practices and how they influence current events. For example, the transition from male-dominated to inclusive female participation can inform discussions about gender dynamics in cultural competitions.

4. **Cultural Significance**:
   - Recognizing the Road March's prestige can help the model infer the broader social implications of winning, such as increased visibility for artists and potential economic benefits.

5. **Diversity of Winners**:
   - The emergence of foreign artists winning the title (e.g., Skinny Fabulous) can lead to discussions about globalization and its impact on local traditions, enhancing the model's ability to reason about cultural exchange and adaptation.

### Conclusion:
By consolidating this information, the model can improve its causal reasoning and logical inference capabilities by understanding the relationships between events, recognizing patterns, and contextualizing cultural phenomena. This knowledge can be applied to a variety of scenarios beyond the Road March, enhancing the model's overall reasoning framework.

cognition.content:
Fact-checking refers to the process of confirming the accuracy of a statement or claim through various sources or methods. 
This process aims to ensure that statements or claims are based on reliable and verifiable information while eliminating inaccurate or misleading content. 
Fact-checking may involve the examination of data, literature, expert opinions, or other trustworthy sources.
In the context of artificial intelligence, model illusion refers to the overconfidence response of the AI. 
When a model exhibits an 'illusion' (a tendency to output deceptive data), it indicates that the training data used by the model does not necessarily support the rationality of its outputs.
You are a scientist researching fact-checking and addressing model illusions in artificial intelligence. 
To answer the following question:
who win road march in trinidad and tobago
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['After a German pop song "Happy Wanderer" by the Obernkirchen Children\'s Choir won the Trinidad & Tobago Road March title in 1955 the rules were amended to restrict songs eligible to be in the road march competition to only songs vocalised by local Trinidad & Tobago artistes. The Road March title is among the most prestigious in Trinidad Carnival. The most such titles have gone to the late Lord Kitchener with eleven wins, ahead of Super Blue with ten wins, Machel Montano also with ten wins and the Mighty Sparrow with eight wins. In the mid-1970s, a woman officially broke through in the male dominated Calypso arena. Calypso Rose was the first female to officially win the Trinidad and Tobago Road March competition in 1977 with her song "Give More Tempo". The following year 1978 with "Come Leh We Jam" in addition to winning the Road March title again, Calypso Rose also won the "Calypso King" competition, the first time a woman had received that award. As a result, the "Calypso King" competition was officially renamed the "Calypso Monarch" competition to take into account that females also take part and have won titles.\n', 'Destra won the Road March title in 2003 at the Labour Day Carnival in Brooklyn, and also placed second in the Trinidad and Tobago Soca Monarch competition in that same year.\n', 'Invader has won the Road March in St. Lucia seven times. In a period from 1970-1972 and again from 1974-1976, Road March winners were imported from Trinidad and Tobago.\n', "Fay-Ann Lyons is a three-time Trinidad and Tobago Carnival Road March champion (2003, 2008, 2009) and the 2009 International Soca Monarch and International Groovy Soca Monarch champion. She created history (again) when she won the International Soca Monarch for the first time in 2009, as the first female to win the Power category, and the first individual (male or female) to win the Power, Groovy and People's Choice awards on Fantastic Friday (aka Carnival Friday) during the finals of the competition which is held annually in Trinidad. She also went on to win the Carnival Road March that year, becoming the first soca artist to win that soca 'triplet' of titles. She is the first (and only) woman to accomplish that feat while pregnant. Fay-Ann is the youngest solo artist (male or female), still actively recording, with multiple wins of the Carnival Road March crown. (Machel Montano is the youngest male with multiple wins, now that he has four solo wins and a joint win with Patrice Roberts). Fay-Ann remains the only female artist who has won the Carnival Road March three times, and is the second to attain back-to-back wins in two consecutive years joining Alison Hinds Of Barbados who won 2 road march titles in 1996 and 1997. Fay-Ann and husband Bunji Garlin also became parents in 2009 to a daughter, Syri, born on February 28, 2009, just a few weeks after Carnival. Fay-Ann has performed at musical events both locally and abroad. Her on-tour performance evGents and locations include: Washington DC (2009) & (2017) BET's 106 & Park (2014), Coachella (2015), Glastonbury Festival (2015), London's Coronet (2015), Berlin Carnival-Germany and, BET X Live (2018).\n", 'Trinidad and Tobago competed at the 2016 UCI Track Cycling World Championships at the Lee Valley VeloPark in London, United Kingdom from 2-4 March 2016. A team of 1 cyclists (0 women, 1 men) was announced to represent the country in the event.\n', 'On June 16, 2019, Ramey represented Five Rivers was crowned as Miss Trinidad and Tobago 2019 held at Naparima Bowl in San Fernando. She succeeded outgoing by Ysabel Bisnath. \n', 'In Trinidad and Tobago the Road March title has been officially given out every year since 1932 (with the exception of the years affected by World War I and World War II when Carnival did not officially take place). Popular Unofficial Road Marches have also been recognized in T&T from since 1834 after slavery was abolished. Prior to World War II, T&T Road Marches were referred to as "Leggos" or "Breakaways" by the general population but were rebranded by the Carnival authorities as the Road March from 1946. Scoring is based upon a register-and-count system devised by a Carnival committee before the start of the parade. \n', '• Tour of Trinidad and Tobago Champion 2013\n', 'First Calypso recordings were made in 1912 so Trinidad & Tobago Road Marches prior to 1912 were not recorded that year but may have been recorded years later after recording technology became available to Calypso pioneers of 1910\'s to 1930\'s. In 2019 Skinny Fabulous of St. Vincent & the Grenadines created history by becoming the second foreign artiste (after the German Obernkirchen Children\'s Choir) and the very first foreign soca artiste to win the prestigious Trinidad & Tobago Road March title with a song called "Famalay" which was vocalised by Skinny Fabulous, Machel Montano and Bunji Garllin. \n', 'In 2015, Trinidad and Tobago won the NACRA Rugby Championship, defeating Mexico 30-16 in the final.\n']

passages:
After a German pop song "Happy Wanderer" by the Obernkirchen Children's Choir won the Trinidad & Tobago Road March title in 1955 the rules were amended to restrict songs eligible to be in the road march competition to only songs vocalised by local Trinidad & Tobago artistes. The Road March title is among the most prestigious in Trinidad Carnival. The most such titles have gone to the late Lord Kitchener with eleven wins, ahead of Super Blue with ten wins, Machel Montano also with ten wins and the Mighty Sparrow with eight wins. In the mid-1970s, a woman officially broke through in the male dominated Calypso arena. Calypso Rose was the first female to officially win the Trinidad and Tobago Road March competition in 1977 with her song "Give More Tempo". The following year 1978 with "Come Leh We Jam" in addition to winning the Road March title again, Calypso Rose also won the "Calypso King" competition, the first time a woman had received that award. As a result, the "Calypso King" competition was officially renamed the "Calypso Monarch" competition to take into account that females also take part and have won titles.
Destra won the Road March title in 2003 at the Labour Day Carnival in Brooklyn, and also placed second in the Trinidad and Tobago Soca Monarch competition in that same year.
Invader has won the Road March in St. Lucia seven times. In a period from 1970-1972 and again from 1974-1976, Road March winners were imported from Trinidad and Tobago.
Fay-Ann Lyons is a three-time Trinidad and Tobago Carnival Road March champion (2003, 2008, 2009) and the 2009 International Soca Monarch and International Groovy Soca Monarch champion. She created history (again) when she won the International Soca Monarch for the first time in 2009, as the first female to win the Power category, and the first individual (male or female) to win the Power, Groovy and People's Choice awards on Fantastic Friday (aka Carnival Friday) during the finals of the competition which is held annually in Trinidad. She also went on to win the Carnival Road March that year, becoming the first soca artist to win that soca 'triplet' of titles. She is the first (and only) woman to accomplish that feat while pregnant. Fay-Ann is the youngest solo artist (male or female), still actively recording, with multiple wins of the Carnival Road March crown. (Machel Montano is the youngest male with multiple wins, now that he has four solo wins and a joint win with Patrice Roberts). Fay-Ann remains the only female artist who has won the Carnival Road March three times, and is the second to attain back-to-back wins in two consecutive years joining Alison Hinds Of Barbados who won 2 road march titles in 1996 and 1997. Fay-Ann and husband Bunji Garlin also became parents in 2009 to a daughter, Syri, born on February 28, 2009, just a few weeks after Carnival. Fay-Ann has performed at musical events both locally and abroad. Her on-tour performance evGents and locations include: Washington DC (2009) & (2017) BET's 106 & Park (2014), Coachella (2015), Glastonbury Festival (2015), London's Coronet (2015), Berlin Carnival-Germany and, BET X Live (2018).
Trinidad and Tobago competed at the 2016 UCI Track Cycling World Championships at the Lee Valley VeloPark in London, United Kingdom from 2-4 March 2016. A team of 1 cyclists (0 women, 1 men) was announced to represent the country in the event.
On June 16, 2019, Ramey represented Five Rivers was crowned as Miss Trinidad and Tobago 2019 held at Naparima Bowl in San Fernando. She succeeded outgoing by Ysabel Bisnath. 
In Trinidad and Tobago the Road March title has been officially given out every year since 1932 (with the exception of the years affected by World War I and World War II when Carnival did not officially take place). Popular Unofficial Road Marches have also been recognized in T&T from since 1834 after slavery was abolished. Prior to World War II, T&T Road Marches were referred to as "Leggos" or "Breakaways" by the general population but were rebranded by the Carnival authorities as the Road March from 1946. Scoring is based upon a register-and-count system devised by a Carnival committee before the start of the parade. 
• Tour of Trinidad and Tobago Champion 2013
First Calypso recordings were made in 1912 so Trinidad & Tobago Road Marches prior to 1912 were not recorded that year but may have been recorded years later after recording technology became available to Calypso pioneers of 1910's to 1930's. In 2019 Skinny Fabulous of St. Vincent & the Grenadines created history by becoming the second foreign artiste (after the German Obernkirchen Children's Choir) and the very first foreign soca artiste to win the prestigious Trinidad & Tobago Road March title with a song called "Famalay" which was vocalised by Skinny Fabulous, Machel Montano and Bunji Garllin. 
In 2015, Trinidad and Tobago won the NACRA Rugby Championship, defeating Mexico 30-16 in the final.
